importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the current status of food aid operations in Gaza, highlighting the ongoing humanitarian crisis and the urgency of expanding aid deliveries.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: This time frame represents the immediate post-ceasefire period, during which food delivery to Gaza is being assessed and scaled up, emphasizing the temporary nature of current access and the risk of further disruption.

keyTakeAways: Food supplies to Gaza remain significantly below the WFP's daily target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 metric tonnes delivered daily.
Only two Israeli-controlled crossings — Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara — are currently operational, severely limiting aid flow.
The UN World Food Programme (WFP) has 26 distribution points open in Gaza, up from five, but still far below the goal of 145 distribution points across the territory.
Humanitarian aid is not reaching northern Gaza due to restrictions on the Salah al-Din Street and lack of access to northern crossings.
Hamas has agreed to hand over the remains of 13 of the 28 Israeli captives, with two more bodies exhumed and delivered as of the article’s date.
The US-brokered ceasefire, supported by President Donald Trump’s 20-point plan, is considered vital to sustaining aid and preventing famine.

Despite some food reaching northern Gaza via southern routes, it is insufficient for the population’s needs, and many Palestinians are storing supplies due to uncertainty about the ceasefire’s duration.

namedEntities.name: WFP
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP is central to the article as the primary agency monitoring and reporting on food supply levels in Gaza, emphasizing the scale and urgency of the humanitarian crisis.

namedEntities.name: Karem Abu Salem
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing into Gaza from Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is one of the two currently operational crossings into Gaza, allowing limited food supplies to enter, and is key to understanding the constraints on humanitarian access.

namedEntities.name: al-Karara
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A border crossing into Gaza from Israel
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This is the second operational crossing, enabling food deliveries to central Gaza, and is essential to assessing the full scope of access limitations.

namedEntities.name: Kissufim
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It represents the Israeli designation for a key humanitarian entry point, showing cross-referencing of crossing names in international reporting.

namedEntities.name: Salah al-Din Street
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major north-south street in Gaza
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The WFP has not been granted access to this route, blocking humanitarian aid from reaching northern Gaza and exacerbating regional food shortages.

namedEntities.name: Rafah border crossing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Border crossing between Gaza and Egypt
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This crossing remains closed, preventing potential access from Egypt and further restricting food delivery options in Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Hamas
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hamas is involved in the return of Israeli captives’ bodies, which is a condition for reopening the Rafah crossing and influencing the stability of the ceasefire.

namedEntities.name: Qassam Brigades
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Qassam Brigades announced the delivery of two more captives' remains, signaling compliance with the ceasefire terms and affecting the timeline for reopening crossings.

namedEntities.name: Benjamin Netanyahu
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He declared the Rafah crossing would remain closed until Hamas returns all captives' bodies, directly impacting humanitarian access to northern Gaza.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: His 20-point peace plan brokered the ceasefire and includes provisions for full humanitarian aid delivery into Gaza, forming a key diplomatic framework for the situation.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The UN World Food Programme reports that daily food deliveries to Gaza have increased following a US-brokered ceasefire but remain far below the target of 2,000 tonnes, with only 750 tonnes entering daily through two Israeli-controlled crossings — Karem Abu Salem and al-Karara. Despite expanding to 26 distribution points, the WFP still falls short of its goal of 145 points across Gaza. The Rafah crossing remains closed, and access to northern Gaza is severely restricted due to blocked routes like Salah al-Din Street and lack of permissions. Hamas has handed over 13 of 28 Israeli captives’ bodies, with two more delivered as of the article’s date. The WFP warns that current supplies are only sufficient for half a million people for two weeks, and many Palestinians are storing food out of fear of future supply disruptions. The article underscores the fragility of the ceasefire and the urgent need to open more crossings to prevent famine, especially in the northern regions of Gaza.
title: WFP says food supplies to Gaza below targets, urges more crossings to open
